name: Pycroscopy
tagline: A suite of utilities for image processing and scientific analysis of nanoscale imaging of materials. Classes implemented here are ported to a high performance computing platform at Oak Ridge National Laboratory.
body:
PyCroscopy
==========

>"They don't think we're microscopists... Let's become pycroscopists then!" 

>S.J to N.L, 2016

0. What?
--------------------
A suite of utilities for image processing and scientific analysis of imaging modalities such as multi-frequency scanning probe microscopy, scanning tunneling spectroscopy, x-ray diffraction microscopy, and transmission electron microscopy.
Classes implemented here are ported to a high performance computing platform at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL).

1. Why?
---------------
There is that little thing called _open science_... 

2. Who?
-----------
This project begun largely as an effort of materials scientists (_and a physicist_) at the Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences <https://www.ornl.gov/facility/cnms> to implement a python library that can withstand the analysis of the gargantuan stream of images that their microscopes generate; with a lot of help from for their friends: the CNMS facility users!
By sharing their approach and code for analyzing materials imaging, they hope that it will benefit the wider community of materials science/physics (and hope so ardently that others would please follow suite see 1. ;-).

3. The Structure
-----------------
The package structure is simple, with 4 modules:
   1. _io_
   2. _processing_
   3. _analysis_
   4. _viz_

Once a microscopy data is converted into an HDF5 format by extending some of the simple classes in _io_. The user has access to the rest of the package structure and quite possibly a lot more! 
(Did we mention HPC?)
